Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: Developing early Holocene records of terrestrial climate in Baffin Bay to understand ice sheet response time to climate change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Elizabeth K. Thomas has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct research and outreach at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and the State University of New York at Buffalo. She will reconstruct climate change of the early Holocene (7-10 thousand years ago) on western Greenland and eastern Baffin Island to better constrain the factors that control ice sheet margin change. Understanding the speed and nature of ice sheet response to climate change is at the forefront of the scientific community and public interest, as this is a major uncertainty of state-of-the-art sea level rise predictions. Dr. Thomas' research will place constraints on the speed and nature of ice sheet response to climate change on human-relevant timescales, with direct benefits to communities working to adapt to sea level rise. Dr. Thomas will broaden participation in Earth Sciences by mentoring undergraduate researchers and developing outreach programs in Amherst, MA and Buffalo, NY, communities with significant populations that are underrepresented in Earth Science. Both of these communities lie near features deposited by the Laurentide Ice Sheet thousands of years ago, and thus provide natural laboratories for learning about ice sheets and discussing challenges that scientists and society face today regarding climate change, ice sheets, and sea level rise.

Quantifying ice sheet responses to climate change is critical for predicting sea level rise in a warming world. During the early Holocene, the Baffin Bay sectors of the Laurentide and Greenland ice sheets advanced rapidly and dramatically, likely in response to abrupt (10s to 100s of years) climate changes at 9.3 and 8.2 ka. The character of early Holocene decadal-scale temperature and precipitation changes in the Baffin Bay region remains unknown, however, so direct comparison of climate and ice sheet reconstructions currently is not possible. Dr. Thomas will use organic compounds (branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers and leaf wax hydrogen isotopes) preserved in lake sediments near the margins of the Greenland and Laurentide ice sheets to reconstruct decadal-scale temperature and precipitation changes. She will then compare the climate reconstructions to ice sheet reconstructions to elucidate ice sheet response time to climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantifying ice sheet responses to climate change is critical for predicting sea level rise in a warming world. Past intervals of rapid climate change on human-relevant timescales provide natural experiments for quantifying ice sheet response to climate change. During the early Holocene (10,000 to 7,000 years ago), the Baffin Bay sectors of the Laurentide and Greenland ice sheets advanced rapidly and dramatically, likely in response to abrupt climate changes at 9,300 and 8,200 years ago. Prior to this research, the character of early Holocene decadal-scale temperature and precipitation changes in the Baffin Bay region was unknown, so direct comparison of climate and ice sheet reconstructions was not possible. To facilitate such comparisons, our work on this project has increased the number of climate and glacier reconstructions in Baffin Bay as follows:

  1. A direct outcome of this project is two temperature and precipitation records near the margins of the Laurentide and Greenland ice sheets spanning 10,000 to 7,000 years ago. We document multiple abrupt cool and dry events, and have attributed this climate change to multiple freshwater outburst events documented in the Hudson Strait. We are working to further test this causal relationship using climate model results that simulate freshwater outburst events in this region.
  2. We have also generated a record that documents greater snowfall on western Greenland 6,000 to 4,000 years ago due to decreased sea ice and higher temperature. This result suggests that the relatively minor retreat of the Greenland Ice Sheet at that time may be explained by greater winter precipitation that offset melt due to warmer summers.
  3. Mountain glaciers around Greenland are also retreating, and understanding the causes of their retreat is also important to predict sea level rise. We have generated a record of Greenland mountain glacier behavior and climate spanning the past 9,000 years, using a novel combination of three proxy records. We found that glaciers in western Greenland respond rapidly and sensitively to climate change in the North Atlantic region.

Understanding the speed and nature of ice sheet response to climate change is at the forefront of the scientific community and public interest, as this is a major uncertainty of state-of-the-art sea level rise predictions. By combining new climate records with existing records of ice sheet and glacier change, this work is placing constraints on the speed and nature of ice sheet response to climate change on human-relevant timescales. These results are relevant for communities working to adapt to sea level rise. The postdoctoral fellow has disseminated information in three main ways: scientific presentations and publications, mentoring of undergraduate researchers, and outreach with programs in Amherst, MA and Buffalo, NY. Outreach and education efforts have been specifically targeted to reach individuals who are underrepresented in Earth Science (e.g., an activity that the postdoctoral fellow led for the Girls Inc. Eureka! program at UMass Amherst exposed more than 50 girls from underperforming schools to STEM activities). The outreach collaborations that the postdoctoral fellow established during this project are continuing, and are therefore reaching larger and broader audiences.
